title: Officer fired for Garner death sues city over termination
text:
Pantaleo’s lawyers and the Police Benevolent Association had vowed to challenge the decision, arguing that Pantaleo’s actions were justified and the decision was tainted by politics. | Eduardo Munoz Alvarez/AP Photo Officer fired for Garner death sues city over termination

Former Police Officer Daniel Pantaleo, who was fired for the death of Eric Garner, filed a lawsuit Wednesday challenging his termination.

NYPD Commissioner James O’Neill fired Pantaleo in August, upholding a department judge’s findings that he used a prohibited chokehold that led to Garner’s death.

Story Continued Below

The ex-cop filed the suit Wednesday in state Supreme Court, said his lawyer, Stuart London. The suit charges the decision to fire the officer was arbitrary and capricious.

Pantaleo’s lawyers and the Police Benevolent Association had vowed to challenge the decision, arguing that Pantaleo’s actions were justified and the decision was tainted by politics.

The officer was attempting to arrest Garner on Staten Island in 2014 in a struggle that was caught on video, where Garner repeatedly cried out “I can’t breathe” before he died.

Rev. Al Sharpton, who had long called for Pantaleo's termination, said the suit was an insult.

"Pantaleo's decision to seek his reinstatement is not only disrespectful to the Police Commissioner and NYPD, but also the Garner family," Sharpton said in a statement Wednesday night. "He has shown no contrition or acknowledgment of his violent actions that ultimately killed Eric Garner."

O’Neill, in announcing the firing this summer, said Pantaleo could “no longer effectively serve as a New York City police officer.”

Pantaleo had been on modified duty since Garner’s death, but still got pay increases and overtime.

His union and lawyer said they had been on the verge of a deal that would have let him give up his job but keep his pension, but it was pulled off the table at the last minute. They blamed the reversal on interference from Mayor Bill de Blasio, who was running for president at the time.

The PBA encouraged a work slowdown by police after the decision, leading to a drop in arrests.

The city will defend the police commissioner’s decision, said Law Department spokesperson Nick Paolucci.
description: The suit charges the decision to fire the officer was arbitrary and capricious.
